curriculums.name: Introduction to Programming (Part 1)
curriculums.shortDescription: This course is ideal for beginners with little to no experience in programming.
curriculums.longDescription: You'll learn the basic building blocks of a high-level programming language (JavaScript) by completing a variety of real-world STEM projects. Throughout the course, you'll try your hand at using essential coding elements such as instructions, variables and conditional statements. At the end of the course, you'll be able to solve numerous problems with code.

units.name: Giving an Instruction
units.task:
To successfully complete this exercise, you must:
  1. Add another robot.forward() instruction to help the robot get to the goal.
  2. The robot cannot leave the designated path.
units.boilerplate:
robot.forward();
?
units.solution:
robot.forward();
robot.forward();
units.tips:
Instruction

Instructions are special words recognized by computers. They enable computers to complete a specific action. Think of them like commands that we can give to our computer. An example of an instruction is robot.forward().

Using the robot.forward() instruction

The robot.forward() instruction is used to make the robot move forward by one square. Like any other JavaScript instruction, robot.forward() is case sensitive and requires precise spelling.
Example of robot.forward()
robot.forward(); // moves the robot forward by one square

Using the Wrong Letter Case in an Instruction

It is important that we respect uppercase and lowercase letters in instruction names as all instructions in JavaScript are case sensitive.
Example of an invalid instruction
robot.Forward(); // wrong spelling: capital F
robot.forward(); // correct spelling

Programmer

Programmers are people who create programs using instructions from a programming language.

Programming Language

Programming languages are groups of instructions recognized by a computer. This course uses the JavaScript programming language.

units.name: Being Precise With Our Instructions
units.task:
To successfully complete this exercise, you must:
  1. Add a robot.right() and robot.forward() instructions to get the robot to the goal.
  2. The robot cannot leave the designated path. Pay close attention to the order of your instructions as it affects your program!
units.tips:
Order of Instructions

As programs are read from top to bottom, the order in which instructions are presented is important.
Example 1
robot.forward();
robot.right();
In the example above, the robot moves forward before turning right.
Example 2
robot.right();
robot.forward();
In the example above, the robot turns right before moving forward.

Using the robot.forward() instruction

The robot.forward() instruction is used to make the robot move forward by one square. Like any other JavaScript instruction, robot.forward() is case sensitive and requires precise spelling.
Example of robot.forward()
robot.forward(); // moves the robot forward by one square

Using the robot.right() Instruction

The robot.right() instruction is used to make the robot turn on itself 90 degrees clockwise. Note that it does not make the robot move in any direction. To complete a right turn, the robot.forward() instruction should be used after a robot.right() instruction.
Example of robot.right()
robot.right();
robot.forward();

units.tips:
Comments

Sometimes we want to leave helpful information in a program for other programmers reading our code or even ourselves. To do so, we can use single line comments which are indicated by a double slash (//). We can also start a multi-line comment by using a slash followed by an asterisk (/*) and then an asterisk followed by a slash (*/) to end the comment.
Example of comments
// This is a comment before a line of code
robot.right();
robot.right(); // this is a comment after a line of code
/* this is a two-
line comment */
robot.forward();

Order of Instructions

As programs are read from top to bottom, the order in which instructions are presented is important.
Example 1
robot.forward();
robot.right();
In the example above, the robot moves forward before turning right.
Example 2
robot.right();
robot.forward();
In the example above, the robot turns right before moving forward.

units.name: Moving Rapidly
units.task:
To successfully complete this exercise, you must:
  1. Use the robot.forward() instruction with a positive numerical value to help the robot reach the goal.
  2. The robot cannot leave the designated path.
units.tips:
Using the robot.forward() Instruction with a Number

The robot.forward() instruction can be used with a number between the parentheses to make the robot move more than one square. Note that the number must be greater than 0 but no more than 10.
Example of robot.forward() with a number
robot.forward(); // robot moves forward one square
robot.forward(6); // robot moves forward 6 squares
robot.forward(13); // invalid, number is greater than 10
robot.forward(-1); // invalid, number is not greater than 0

units.tips:
Algorithm

A specific set of steps to solve a problem. For example, think of a cake cooking recipe. We cannot apply the frosting to the cake before cooking the cake.

Parameter

A parameter is a value that we give to an instruction to give more details. A parameter will usually change the outcome of an instruction. Some parameters are optional while others are required. Every parameter in an instruction is separated by a comma.
Example of parameters
robot.forward(); // robot.forward() with no parameter
robot.forward(6); // robot.forward() with the optional number parameter
square.draw(3, 7); // square.draw() with the two required coordinate parameters

Using the robot.forward() Instruction with a Number

The robot.forward() instruction can be used with a number between the parentheses to make the robot move more than one square. Note that the number must be greater than 0 but no more than 10.

units.name: The Importance of a Language
units.task:
To successfully complete this exercise, you must:
  1. Complete the building plan using square.draw(). Add a square at the two following coordinates: (3, 4) and (3, 7).
units.tips:
Using the square.draw() Instruction (with Cities)

The square.draw() instruction is used to draw squares on the grid at a set of coordinates. The square.draw() instruction has 2 required parameters and 2 optional parameters. The parameters must be put in the following order: square.draw(x, y, [type], [direction])
The x coordinate must be a number between 0 and 14 and is required
The y coordinate must be a number between 0 and 9 and is required
The tile type can be any of the following: "house", "road", "tree", "pool" [optional]
The tile direction can be any of the following: "vertical", "horizontal", "junction-3L", "junction-3R" [optional]
(Note that the tile direction only affects the tiles of type "road")
Example of square.draw()
square.draw(0, 7, "house"); // creates a house at (0,7)
square.draw(3, 5, "road", "vertical"); // creates a vertical road at (3,5)
square.draw(17, 7, "tree"); // invalid, x coordinate greater than 14
Square.draw(0, 0, "pool"); // invalid, S of square written in uppercase
square.draw(1, 6, house); // invalid, house missing surrounding quotation marks (" ")

units.name: That's a House

units.tips:
Using Text as a Parameter

Some instructions use text as one of their parameter. When text is used as parameter, it is important that it is fully surrounded by quotation marks (" "). If the text is not surrounded by quotation marks, the program will think it is a variable.
Text as a parameter
square.draw(0, 7, "green"); // "green" is a text parameter
square.draw(3, 5, blue"); // invalid, blue is missing an opening quotation mark
square.draw(1, 1, orange); // invalid, orange missing surrounding quotation marks (" ")

Assigning a Value to a Variable

Assigning a value to a variable means to give it a value. We can assign a value to a variable by referencing its name followed by the assignment operator (=) and a value.
If the variable is a new variable, we must use the instruction var before the variable name. The var instruction is required to create a new variable, however it should not be used with an existing variable.
Example of assigning a value to a new and an existing variable
var variableName = 42; // assigns a value of 42 to a new variable
variableName = 52; // assigns a value of 52 to an existing variable
The value we assign to a variable can be of many different types and can even be the result of a calculation.

units.tips:
Naming a Variable

The name of a variable is important as it is the only way we can refer to its value. A variable name cannot contain spaces or begin with a number.
Additionally, variable names are regularly written in camelCase to make them easier to read. Names written camelCase use an uppercase letter for the first letter of every word (except the first word).
Example of variable names
var largeGreenApple; // valid name written in proper camelCase
var verylongvariablename; // valid name but not written in camelCase
var another long variable; // invalid name, contains spaces
var 25apples; // invalid name, begins with a number
var dollars100; // valid name, number is at the end

Case-Sensitive Variable Names

Variable names are case sensitive. If two variables have the same name but with different uppercase/lowercase letters, they will be considered as two unique variables. Note that it is not a good practice to have two variables with similar names, as it can easily lead to confusion.
Example of variable names
var aVariableName; // this creates a variable
var avariablename; // this creates a different variable

If the variable is a new variable, we must use the instruction var before the variable name. The var instruction is required to create a new variable, however it should not be used with an existing variable.

units.tips:
Using Variables with an Undefined Value

The default value of a variable is undefined. For this reason, it is important that we assign a value to a variable before using it, otherwise we may get strange results.
Example of undefined variable
var coins; // value of coins is undefined
var score = coins * 10; // undefined multiplied by 10 is NaN
In the above code example, the variable score will receive a value of NaN, short for Not a Number, because the result of the expression undefined multiplied by 10 is not something that can be calculated.

Using a Variable in an Assignment Operation

Sometimes a variable will be used to assign a value to another variable. In those cases, the value of the variable on the right of the assignment operator (=) will be looked up then the variable on the left will receive its value.
Example of a variable used in an assignment
var firstNumber = 5;
var secondNumber = 10 + firstNumber; // secondNumber receives a value of 15
To calculate the value of secondNumber, we first look at the value of firstNumber, which is 5, and then calculate the sum of 10 plus 5. Once the result 15 is known, we assign it to the variable secondNumber. Note that the variable firstNumber must be created and have a value before it is used to calculate secondNumber.

Assigning a New Value to a Variable Using its Existing Value

Since the right side of an assignment operation is always calculated first, we can use a variable's current value to calculate a new value. To do this, it is important that the variable has value, otherwise the result will be NaN (Not a Number).
Example of using a current value to calculate a new value
var lives = 3;
lives = lives - 1; // lives will be equal to 2, the current value of lives (3) minus 1
var score = score + 100; // invalid, score will be NaN since score has no initial value

units.tips:
Output

An output is information returned to us by a program. The sounds coming out of a speaker, or a page from a printer are examples of outputs.
An example of an instruction to create a text output is the console.log() instruction.

Using the console.log() Instruction

The console.log() instruction allows us to create a text output. The instruction has one parameter. Typically, the parameter is a string. The parameter will be outputted to the program's console.
Note that the string given as a parameter can be a concatenated string.
Example of console.log()
console.log("Hello!"); // displays: Hello!
console.log("Hello " + "world!"); // displays the concatenated string: Hello world!
console.log(Hello!); // invalid, missing quotation marks (" ")

units.name: A Variable Output
units.task:

console.log(?);

units.tips:
Assigning a Value to a Variable

Assigning a value to a variable means to give it a value. We can assign a value to a variable by referencing its name followed by the assignment operator (=) and a value.
If the variable is a new variable, we must use the instruction var before the variable name. The var instruction is required to create a new variable, however it should not be used with an existing variable.
Example of assigning a value to a new and an existing variable
var variableName = 42; // assigns a value of 42 to a new variable
variableName = 52; // assigns a value of 52 to an existing variable
The value we assign to a variable can be of many different types and can even be the result of a calculation.
Example of assigning a value to variables
var lives; // creates a variable named lives with a value of undefined
var score = 42; // creates a variable named score and assigns it the value of 42
lives = 3; // assigns the value of 3 to the existing variable named lives
score = 2 + 2; // assigns the sum of 2 + 2 (4) to the variable score
var name = "EduCode"; // creates a variable named name and assigns it a value of "EduCode"

Using the console.log() Instruction

The console.log() instruction allows us to create a text output. The instruction has one parameter. Typically, the parameter is a string. The parameter will be outputted to the program's console.
Note that the string given as a parameter can be a concatenated string.
Example of console.log()
console.log("Hello!"); // displays: Hello!
console.log("Hello " + "world!"); // displays the concatenated string: Hello world!
console.log(Hello!); // invalid, missing quotation marks (" ")

Using a Variable in the console.log() Instruction

We can use a variable as a parameter to the console.log() instruction. The value of the variable will be outputted to the program's console.
Note that the name of the variable must not be surrounded by quotation marks, otherwise it will be treated as a string.
Example of console.log() with a variable
var myName = "EduCode";
console.log(myName); // displays the text: EduCode
var aNumber = 42;
console.log(aNumber); // displays the number: 42
var aVariable = "Coding is fun!";
console.log(aVariable); // displays the text: Coding is fun!
console.log("aVariable"); // displays the text: aVariable

Using the prompt() Instruction

units.tips:
Data Types

The value of a variable has a type. It is important to consider the type of data a variable holds when performing operations. Some common types are numbers and strings.

Strings

String are values that we can use to represent text. A string always begins and ends with a quotation mark. Multiple strings can be combined using the concatenation operator (+).
Example of strings
var myName = "EduCode";
var aSentence = "Coding is fun!";
var anotherSentence = I love coding!; // invalid, missing quotation marks (" ")
Strings can also be used to represent numbers. However these numbers cannot be used in mathematical operations without first using the Number() instruction.
Example of strings representing numbers
var aStringNumber = "450"; // text representation of 450
var result = aStringNumber + 10; // result will be 45010

Numbers

Numbers are values that we can use in mathematical operations. Numbers must be written with no spaces in between the digits and decimals must be separated using a dot (.) not a comma (,).
Example of numbers
var aNumber = 42;
var aVeryLargeNumber = 10000000;
var anotherLargeNumber = 100 000 000; // invalid, contains spaces
var aDecimalNumber = 1.15;
var anotherDecimalNumber = 1,15; // invalid, uses comma instead of dot

Combining Strings and Other Values (Concatenation)

The result of the + operator depends on the type of data that is being used.
If the two values being added are numbers, then the + operator will work as the addition operator in math.
However, when used with a string, the + symbol is used as the concatenation operator and combines the values to form a string.
Example of + symbol
var result = 10 + 10; // number + number, result is 20 (number)
result = "10" + "10"; // string + string, result is 1010 (string)
result = "10" + 10; // string + number, result is 1010 (string)
result = "10" + (10 + 10); // string + (number + number), result is 1020 (string)

Not a Number (NaN) is a special value used by JavaScript when a mathematical expression cannot be calculated.

units.name: Quiz 4
units.description: Data Types

questions.question: In programming, what is a string?

answers.explanation: A string is text that is surrounded by quotation marks. If it does not have quotations marks, it is an instruction or a variable.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true?

answers.answer: The value returned by a prompt() instruction is always a string.
answers.explanation: All values returned by a prompt() are strings, including numbers.

answers.answer: The sum of two strings is a number (ex: "5" + "3" = 8).
Data can never be converted to another type.

questions.question: Select the two valid data types in the following list:

answers.explanation: Numbers are a data type. They can be used in calculations.
Strings are a data type. They can be used to represent text.

questions.question: True or false. A number entered in a prompt() should always be converted to a number type before being used in a mathematical operation.

answers.explanation: Numbers entered in a prompt() are returned as strings, which can cause strange results when used in mathematical operations.

questions.question:
What is the final value of the variable result?
var first = "7";
var second = "3";
var result = first + second;

answers.explanation: Since both values are strings and not numbers, the program will add the two strings together to create the string <string>"73"</string>.

questions.question:
What is the final value of the variable result?
var first = 4;
var second = "2";
second = Number(second);
var result = first + second;

answers.explanation: The string <string>"2"</string> is converted to a number, so the program adds the two numbers together.

questions.question: True or false. The Number() instruction can also be written with a lowercase "n" (ex: number()).

answers.explanation: The Number() instruction must always be written with an uppercase "N".

units.tips:
Booleans

Booleans are a data type with only two possible values: true or false.
Any expression using a relational operator will return a Boolean value.
Example of Boolean values
var iLikeCereals = true;

units.tips:
Booleans

Booleans are a data type with only two possible values: true or false.
Any expression using a relational operator will return a Boolean value.
Example of Boolean values

var isGreaterThan18 = 10 > 18; // isGreaterThan18 will be false
var age = 19;
var ageIsGreaterThan18 = age > 18; // ageIsGreaterThan18 will be true

Relational Operators

Relational operators allow us to compare values. They always return a Boolean value.
The relational operators are: greater than (>), less than (<), greater or equal to (>=), less or equal to (<=), equal (==), not equal (!=).
Example of relational operators
var result = 10 > 5; // true, 10 is greater than 5
result = 10 < 5; // false, 10 is not less than 5
result = 10 <= 10; // true, 10 is equal to 10
result = 10 < 10; // false, 10 is not less than 10
result = 15 == 10; // false, 15 is not equal to 10
result = 15 == 15; // true, 15 is equal to 15
result = 5 != 7; // true, 5 is not equal to 7
result = 5 != 5; // false, 5 is equal to 5

  2. Replace the second question mark with an instruction to assign to myBool the Boolean value returned by the comparison of 7 equal to 5.
units.tips:
Strings and the Equal/Not Equal Operators

The relational operators equal and not equal can be used to compare strings.
The equal operator (==) will return true if both strings are identical, including the case of each letter.
The not equal operator (!=) will return true if the two strings are different by at least one letter, including the case of each letter.
Example of string comparison
var result = "EduCode" == "EduCode"; // true
result = "Coding" == "Programming"; // false
result = "EduCode" == "Educode"; // false, uppercase "C" is different
result = "EduCode" != "EduCode"; // false, both strings identical
result = "EduCode" != "Educode"; // true, uppercase "C" is different

Relational Operators

Relational operators allow us to compare values. They always return a Boolean value.
The relational operators are: greater than (>), less than (<), greater or equal to (>=), less or equal to (<=), equal (==), not equal (!=).
Example of relational operators
var result = 10 > 5; // true, 10 is greater than 5
result = 10 < 5; // false, 10 is not less than 5
result = 10 <= 10; // true, 10 is equal to 10
result = 10 < 10; // false, 10 is not less than 10
result = 15 == 10; // false, 15 is not equal to 10
result = 15 == 15; // true, 15 is equal to 15
result = 5 != 7; // true, 5 is not equal to 7
result = 5 != 5; // false, 5 is equal to 5

Using the Assignment Operator (=) Instead of the Equal Operator (==)

A common mistake when using the equal operator (==) is to use only one "=" symbol. Instead of comparing the two values, we will be doing an assignment operation.
Example of using the assignment operator instead of the equal operator
var x = 10;
console.log(x = 15); // instead of checking if x is equal to 15, x will take the value 15

  4. The final value of greatestNumber is the number with the greatest value.

units.tips:

The if statement and else if statement are similar in purpose, however, there is one key difference. With multiple if statements, we can control multiple code blocks independently, where the result of each if statement does not affect the other if statements. With else if statements, each code block is dependant, meaning that only one code block will be executed.
Example with multiple if statements
var weight = 17;

if(weight > 4)
{
  // this code block is executed
  console.log("weight is greater than 4!");
}
if(weight > 8)
{
  // this code block is also executed
  console.log("weight is greater than 8!");
}
if(weight > 16)
{
  // this code block is also executed
  console.log("weight is greater than 16!");
}
In the above example, we get three messages: "weight is greater than 4!", "weight is greater than 8!" and "weight is greater than 16!". This is because even if the first if statement is true, the second and third if statements are still executed.
Example with else if statements
var weight = 17;

if(weight > 4)
{
  // this code block is executed
  console.log("weight is greater than 4!");
}
else if(weight > 8)
{
  // this code block is not executed, because the first one was executed
  console.log("weight is greater than 8!");
}
else if(weight > 16)
{
  // this code block is not executed, because the first one was executed
  console.log("weight is greater than 16!");
}
If we replace the second and third if statements by else if statements, like in the code above, we only get one message: "weight is greater than 4!". This is because as soon as one condition is true, we don't check the other statements.

Else If Statement

An else if statement is another conditional statement that we can add to an existing if statement to add one or more code blocks controlled by conditions.
Note that no matter how many else if statements are added to a single if statement, only one code block will be executed. The conditions are checked in order from top to bottom and as soon as one condition is met, the code block is executed and the other conditions are ignored.
Example of multiple else if statements

{
  // not executed, condition is false
  console.log("myVariable is greater than 15!");
}
else if(myVariable > 10)
{
  // executed, condition is true
  console.log("myVariable is greater than 10!");
}
else if(myVariable > 5)
{
  // not executed, another code block has been executed
  console.log("myVariable is greater than 5!");
}
In the above example, because the variable myVariable has a value of 11, the message "myVariable is greater than 10!" is displayed. The first code block is ignored because myVariable is not greater than 15 and the last code block is also ignored because the second code block has already been executed.

units.description: Nested If Statements

questions.question: True or false. An if statement can contain multiple if statements inside its code block.

answers.explanation: Code blocks are used to group instructions, and we can put any instruction inside of it.

questions.question: Select all the statements that are true.

answers.answer: An if statement inside of another if statement's code block is always executed, even if the condition of the first if statement is false.
An if statement inside of another if statement's code block will only be executed if the condition of the first if statement is true.
answers.explanation: An if statement inside a code block will only be executed if the code block is executed.

answers.answer: An if statement inside of another if statement's code block cannot have an else statement.
An if statement inside of another if statement's code block cannot have an else if statement.

questions.question:
What is the output of the following program?
var temperature = 16;
  
if(temperature > 10)
{
  console.log("Temperature is greater than 10");

  if(temperature > 15)
  {
    console.log("Temperature is greater than 15");
  }
}

answers.answer: Two messages: Temperature is greater than 10 and Temperature is greater than 15
answers.explanation: Since temperature > 10 is true, the first message is displayed. Then, since the code block is executed and temperature > 15 is also true, the second message is also displayed.

if(temperature > 10)
{

  }
}
else
{
  console.log("Temperature is less than 10");
}

answers.answer: Two messages: Temperature is greater than 10 and Temperature is greater than 15

answers.explanation: Since temperature > 10 is false, the code block of the else statement is executed.

questions.question:

var temperature = 11;

if(temperature > 10)
{
  if(temperature > 15)
  {
    console.log("Temperature is greater than 15");
  }
  else
  {
    console.log("Temperature is between 10 and 15");
  }
}
else
{
  console.log("Temperature is less than 10");
}

answers.explanation: Since temperature > 10 is true, the code block of the first if statement is executed. Then, since temperature > 15 is false, the code block of the first else is executed.

answers.answer: Two messages: Temperature is less than 10 and Temperature is between 10 and 15

questions.question:
What is the problem with the following program?
var weight = 3;
  
if(weight > 10)
{
  console.log("Weight is greater than 10");

  if(weight < 5)
  {
    console.log("Weight is less than 5");
  }
}

answers.answer: The second if statement can never execute. A number cannot be both greater than 10 and less than 5.
answers.explanation: The code is illogical. The inner if statement should be outside the code block of the first if statement.

answers.answer: There is an if statement inside the code block of another if statement.
The condition of the first and second if statements should be switched.

questions.question:
What is the problem with the following program?
var weight = 7;

if(weight < 15)
{
  console.log("Weight is less than 15");

  else
  {
    console.log("Weight is greater than 15");
  }
}

answers.answer: The else statement should be replaced with an if statement to check if weight is greater than 15.
The else statement inside the code block of the first if statement should be moved after the if statement.
answers.explanation: An else statement cannot be alone in a conditional statement. For this code to be valid, the else statement should be outside the code block, immediately after the last closing curly brace (}).

Creating and Using a Variable

To create a variable, we use the var instruction followed by a name.
To assign a value to a variable we have previously created, we reference its name without using the var instruction.
By default, the value of a variable is undefined.
Example of creating and using a variable
var score; // creates a new variable named score with a value of undefined
score = 42; // gives the value of 42 to the existing variable named score
var lives = 3; // creates a new variable named lives with a value of 3

If Statement

The if statement is a type of conditional statement that allow us to control if a code block will be executed. They have two main parts: a Boolean condition, and code to execute if the condition is true.
Example of an if statement
var money = 8;
if(money > 5) // the Boolean condition, between parentheses
{
  // everything between the curly braces ({}) will
  // only be executed if money is greater than 5
  console.log("You can buy the game!");
}
In the above example, if the value of the variable money is greater than 5, then the console.log() is executed, otherwise nothing happens.

If Statement

AND Operator (&&)

The AND operator is a logical operator that allows us to check if two or more Boolean values are true.
An expression that uses the AND operator will only be true if all the conditions that make up the expression are true.
The operator is represented using two ampersand symbols (&&).

var result = true && true; // result is true

units.tips:
Else If Statement

An else if statement is another conditional statement that we can add to an existing if statement to add one or more code blocks controlled by conditions.
Note that no matter how many else if statements are added to a single if statement, only one code block will be executed. The conditions are checked in order from top to bottom and as soon as one condition is met, the code block is executed and the other conditions are ignored.
Example of multiple else if statements
var myVariable = 11;

if(myVariable > 15)
{
  // not executed, condition is false
  console.log("myVariable is greater than 15!");
}
else if(myVariable > 10)
{
  // executed, condition is true
  console.log("myVariable is greater than 10!");
}
else if(myVariable > 5)
{
  // not executed, another code block has been executed
  console.log("myVariable is greater than 5!");
}
In the above example, because the variable myVariable has a value of 11, the message "myVariable is greater than 10!" is displayed. The first code block is ignored because myVariable is not greater than 15 and the last code block is also ignored because the second code block has already been executed.

Using the OR Operator (||)

The OR operator is a logical operator that allows us to check if at least one or more Boolean values are true.
An expression that uses the OR operator will be true if at least one condition that makes up the expression is true.
The operator is represented using two vertical bars (||).
Example of the OR operator
var result = true || true; // result is true
result = false || true; // result is true
result = true || false; // result is true
result = false || false; // result is false

Else Statement

An else statement is another conditional statement that we can add to an existing if statement to add an additional code block. The code block controlled by the else statement is only executed if the condition of the if statement is false.
Note that the else statement does not have a condition of its own, and cannot be used without an if statement.
Example of an else statement
var money = 8;
if(money > 5) // this condition will control both code blocks
{
  // will only execute if money is greater than 5
  console.log("You can buy the game!");
}
else // notice that there is no condition here
{
  // will only execute if money is NOT greater than 5
  console.log("You don't have enough money to buy the game!");
}

result = true && false; // result is false

var result = true || true; // result is true
result = false || true; // result is true
result = true || false; // result is true
result = false || false; // result is false

Example of while loop
var x = 0;
while(x < 2)
{

  x = x + 1;
}

Now that x is equal to 2, the condition is false and the loop stops.

Infinite Loops

Infinite loops are a type of bug that happen when the condition of a loop can never be false.
Example of an infinite loop

while(count > 0)
{
  console.log(count);
  // we are missing an instruction here to decrease

}
In the above example, the value of the control variable never changes and therefore the condition "count > 0" is always true. This causes the loop to display the number 3 over and over.

while(count > 0); // notice the semicolon here
{
  console.log(count);
  count = count - 1;
}
The computer will understand the above code as follows:
Example of an infinite loop caused by a semicolon

while(count > 0)
{

}
console.log(count);
// notice how the value of the control

count = count - 1;

units.name: Quiz 10
units.description: While Loops

questions.question: True or false. A while loop must be controlled by a Boolean condition.

answers.explanation: A while loop can only do two things: continue looping or stop looping. To control this, we use true to continue and false to stop. Therefore, all loops are controlled by Boolean conditions.

questions.question: What is an iteration?

answers.answer: The instruction that increases the value of the control variable of a loop (ex: x = x + 1;)
A single execution of the instructions in the code block of a loop
answers.explanation: An iteration is the full completion of the code block of the loop.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true?

answers.answer: A while loop calculates how many times it must execute the instructions in its code block. This means that the loop "knows" how many times it must iterate.
A while loop checks its condition at every iteration. This means that the loop never "knows" how many iterations it must complete, it will only stop once the condition is false.
answers.explanation: As long as the condition is true, the loop will continue to iterate. The while loop doesn't "know" how many times it must iterate.

answers.answer: We must give a number to the while loop to tell it to iterate that many times (ex: while(10))

questions.question:
What is the output of the following program?
var countdown = 3;

while(countdown >= 0)
{
  console.log(countdown);
  countdown = countdown - 1;
}

answers.explanation: The variable <var>countdown</var> begins at 3, so the first output will be 3. It then goes down by one until it reaches 0. Since the condition checks if <var>countdown</var> is also equal to 0, the loop does one last iteration.

questions.question:
What is the output of the following program?
var money = 10;
var year = 0;

while(year < 3)
{
  console.log(money);
  money = money + 10;
  year = year + 1;
}

answers.explanation: The order of the instructions is important here: console.log() is executed before the value of money is increased, so the output is: 10, 20, 30. After money is set to 30, the variable year is increased to 3, which will stop the loop.

questions.question:
Is the following program stuck in an infinite loop?
var countdown = 3;

while(countdown >= 0)
{
  console.log(countdown);
  countdown = countdown + 1;
}

answers.explanation: The variable <var>countdown</var> begins at 3 and increases at every iteration of the loop. The loop stops once <var>countdown</var> is less than 0, which can never happen.

answers.answer: No, the while loop will end after a few iterations.

questions.question:
Why is the following program stuck in an infinite loop?
var countdown = 10;

while(countdown > 0)
{
  console.log(countdown);
}

answers.answer: The condition of the loop is not a Boolean condition.
The value of the control variable never changes.
answers.explanation: The value of countdown begins at 10 and never changes. Therefore, the condition countdown > 0 never becomes false.

answers.answer: The name of the variable causes an infinite loop.
There should be a semicolon after the while instruction: while(countdown > 0);

units.tips:
Using a Sentinel Value to Control A Loop

A sentinel value is a special value that is used to stop a loop. Typically, the loop will not end until the sentinel value is entered. This is often used to create menus.
Example of sentinel value
var userChoice = "";
while(userChoice != "Q")
{
  userChoice = prompt("Please enter an option (or Q to quit)");
}
In the above example, the loop keeps asking the user to pick an option in the menu, until they enter the letter "Q".

units.tips:
Else If Statement

An else if statement is another conditional statement that we can add to an existing if statement to add one or more code blocks controlled by conditions.
Note that no matter how many else if statements are added to a single if statement, only one code block will be executed. The conditions are checked in order from top to bottom and as soon as one condition is met, the code block is executed and the other conditions are ignored.
Example of multiple else if statements
var myVariable = 11;

if(myVariable > 15)
{
  // not executed, condition is false
  console.log("myVariable is greater than 15!");
}
else if(myVariable > 10)
{
  // executed, condition is true
  console.log("myVariable is greater than 10!");
}
else if(myVariable > 5)
{
  // not executed, another code block has been executed
  console.log("myVariable is greater than 5!");
}
In the above example, because the variable myVariable has a value of 11, the message "myVariable is greater than 10!" is displayed. The first code block is ignored because myVariable is not greater than 15 and the last code block is also ignored because the second code block has already been executed.

Relational Operators

Relational operators allow us to compare values. They always return a Boolean value.
The relational operators are: greater than (>), less than (<), greater or equal to (>=), less or equal to (<=), equal (==), not equal (!=).
Example of relational operators
var result = 10 > 5; // true, 10 is greater than 5
result = 10 < 5; // false, 10 is not less than 5
result = 10 <= 10; // true, 10 is equal to 10
result = 10 < 10; // false, 10 is not less than 10
result = 15 == 10; // false, 15 is not equal to 10
result = 15 == 15; // true, 15 is equal to 15
result = 5 != 7; // true, 5 is not equal to 7
result = 5 != 5; // false, 5 is equal to 5

Loops with more than One Condition

A loop can be controlled by multiple conditions, even if the loop is controlled by a sentinel value.
To do so, we can use a logical operator to combine multiple conditions into a single expression.
Example of multiple conditions in a loop
var userChoice = "";
var attempts = 0;
while(userChoice != "Q" && attempts < 3)
{
  userChoice = prompt("Please enter an option (or Q to quit)");
  attempts = attempts + 1;
}
The above loop will continue to execute as long as the user choice is different than "Q" and that less than 3 attempts have been made. This means that if the user enters the letter "Q" or makes more than 3 attempts, the loop will end.
Notice that only one of two conditions need to be false to end the loop, because the overall expression then becomes false.

questions.question: What is a sentinel value?

{

{

For loops are another type of loop, that allow us to repeat the code in a code block until a certain condition becomes false.

Example of a for loop
for(var x = 0; x < 2; x = x + 1)

In the above code, the condition "x < 2" is initially true The code block is executed, displaying the message: "x is equal to 0" and then the value of x is increased by 1.
The condition is checked a second time and because it is still true, the program outputs "x is equal to 1". The value of x is increased by 1 again.
Now that x is equal to 2, the condition is false and the loop stops.

Components of a For Loop

Like a while loop, a for loop requires a control variable, a condition and an instruction to change value of the control variable.
Unlike a while loop, a for loop keeps these 3 components at the start of the loop.
Example of a for loop
for(var x = 0; x < 2; x = x + 1)
{
  console.log("x is equal to: " + x);
}
The first component, "var x = 0", is called the initialization and it is only executed once at the beginning of the loop. This is where the initial value of the control variable is normally set.
The second component, "x < 2", is called the condition and it is executed before every iteration of the loop. This is where we check if the loop should continue.
The third component, "x = x + 1", is called the increment and it is executed after every iteration. This is where the value of the control variable normally changes.

Putting a Semicolon after a For Loop

Unlike a while loop, placing a semicolon after the parentheses of a for loop will NOT cause an infinite loop.
This is because the iteration components of the for loop are part of the instruction itself and are not inside the code block.
Instead of an infinite loop, the program will iterate over an empty code block and then execute the instruction inside the code block once after the loop.
For example, if you write the following code:
Example of using a semicolon after a for loop
for(var myVar = 0; myVar < 3; myVar = myVar + 1); // notice the semicolon here
{
  console.log("Current value of myVar: " + myVar);
}
The computer will understand the above code as follows:
Iterating over empty code block due to semicolon
for(var myVar = 0; myVar < 3; myVar = myVar + 1) // this will iterate as normal
{
  // but the code block of the loop is understood as being empty
}
console.log("Current value of myVar: " + myVar); // executed only once

Increment (++) and Decrement (--) Operators

A common operation in programming is to increase or decrease the value of a variable by one. For this reason, there are two operators that are shortcuts for these two operations.

While Loops

While loops are a type of loop that allow us to repeat the code in a code block until a certain condition becomes false.
Example of while loop
var x = 0;
while(x < 2)
{

Changing a While Loop into a For Loop

We can always use a while loop or a for loop in any given situation. To do so, we must identify the three components: the control variable, the condition and the increment. Then, we select the loop that is more appropriate for the problem.
Changing a while loop into a for loop
var x = 0; // control variable (first component of for loop)
while(x < 2) // condition (second component of for loop)
{
  console.log("The value of x is " + x);
  x = x + 1; // increment (third component of for loop)
}

for(var x = 0; x < 2; x = x + 1)
{

}

units.name: The Collatz Conjecture
units.description:
You've got this!
The Collatz conjecture is an interesting mathematical phenomenon. The conjecture states that any positive whole number passed through the following algorithm will end up with a value of 1 after a fixed number of iterations. No one has ever found a number that doesn't end to 1 eventually. Let's build a program to test the algorithm and see if we can find a number that won't end up to a value of 1!
Collatz's Conjecture Algorithm:
  1. Start with any positive whole number (number with no decimals).
  2. If the number is even, divide the number by 2 (n = n / 2).
  3. If the number is odd, multiply the number by 3 and add 1 (n = 3 x n + 1).
  4. If the number is now equal to 1, stop.
  5. If the number is still not equal to 1, go back to step (b).
For example, say our starting number is 12. We get the following sequence:
12 (even, divide by 2)
 6 (even, divide by 2)
 3 (odd, multiply by 3 and add 1)
10 (even, divide by 2)
 5 (odd, multiply by 3 and add 1)
16 (even, divide by 2)
 8 (even, divide by 2)
 4 (even, divide by 2)
 2 (even, divide by 2)
 1.

  2. Replace the second question mark with the 3 components required to complete the for loop. The control variable of the for loop should be named divider. The for loop should iterate from 2 to the value of currentNumber minus 1. units.tips:
For Loops

For loops are another type of loop, that allow us to repeat the code in a code block until a certain condition becomes false.
Unlike a while loop, a for loop keeps all of its iteration components in one place.
Example of a for loop
for(var x = 0; x < 2; x = x + 1)
{
  console.log("x is equal to: " + x);
}
In the above code, the condition "x < 2" is initially true The code block is executed, displaying the message: "x is equal to 0" and then the value of x is increased by 1.
The condition is checked a second time and because it is still true, the program outputs "x is equal to 1". The value of x is increased by 1 again.
Now that x is equal to 2, the condition is false and the loop stops.

Nested Loops

We can put a loop inside another loop to create a nested loop (this is similar to nested conditional statements). The first loop is called the outer loop, while the second loop is called the inner loop. Nested loops can be made with either for loops or while loops.
Example of a nested loop
console.log("outer loop starts");
for(var x = 0; x < 2; x = x + 1) // outer loop
{
  console.log("inner loop starts");
  for(var y = 0; y < 2; y = y + 1) // inner loop
  {
    console.log("x is equal to " + x + " and y is equal to " + y);
  }
  console.log("inner loop is done");
}
console.log("outer loop is done");
The program will begin by doing one iteration of the outer loop, which will execute all the iterations of the inner loop. Then, the program will do the next iteration of the outer loop, which will restart the inner loop, redoing all the iterations once more. This continues until the outer loop completes all of its iterations.
The output of the above program is as follows:
outer loop starts
inner loop starts
x is equal to 0 and y is equal to 0
x is equal to 0 and y is equal to 1
inner loop is done
inner loop starts
x is equal to 1 and y is equal to 0
x is equal to 1 and y is equal to 1
inner loop is done
outer loop is done

units.tips:
Instructions

Les instructions sont des mots spciaux reconnus par les ordinateurs. Elles permettent aux ordinateurs d'accomplir une action spcifique. Elles reprsentent des commandes que nous pouvons donner l'ordinateur. Un exemple d'instruction est robot.forward().

Instruction robot.forward()

L'instruction robot.forward() est utilise pour faire avancer le robot d'une case. Comme toutes les autres instructions de JavaScript, robot.forward() est sensible la casse et nous devons l'crire exactement comme indiqu ci-dessous.
Exemple de robot.forward()
robot.forward(); // fait avancer le robot d'une case

Instructions sensibles la casse

Il est important de respecter les lettres majuscules et minuscules en crivant le nom des instructions, puisque toutes les instructions en JavaScript sont sensibles la casse.
Exemple d'instruction incorrecte
robot.Forward(); // incorrect: "forward" prend un "f" minuscule
robot.forward(); // correct

Programmeuses et programmeurs

Les programmeuses et les programmeurs sont des personnes qui crent des programmes l'aide des instructions d'un langage de programmation.

Langage de programmation

Les langages de programmation sont des groupes d'instructions reconnues par un ordinateur. Dans ce cours, nous utilisons le langage de programmation JavaScript.

units.tips:
Variable

Les variables sont des endroits spciaux dans un programme qui possdent un nom et dans lesquels nous pouvons mettre une valeur. Les variables sont comme des botes de carton, avec une tiquette qui indique leur nom. Le contenu de la bote reprsente la valeur de la variable.
Exemple de variable
var pointage = 42; // cre une variable appele pointage avec une valeur de 42

units.tips:
Cration et utilisation d'une variable

Pour crer une variable, nous utilisons l'instruction var suivie d'un nom.
Pour donner une valeur une variable que nous avons cre, nous utilisons son nom, sans l'instruction var.
Par dfaut, la valeur d'une variable est undefined, c'est--dire non dfinie.
Exemple de cration et d'utilisation d'une variable
var pointage; // cre une nouvelle variable appele pointage avec une valeur non dfinie
pointage = 42; // donne la valeur 42  la variable pointage existante
var vies = 3; // cre une nouvelle variable appele vies et lui donne la valeur 3

Utilisation des variables avec valeur non dfinie

Utilisation d'une variable dans une affectation

Lorsque nous avons obtenu le rsultat de 15, nous l'affectons la variable deuxiemeNombre. units.tips:
Un jeu d'obstacles

Le jeu d'obstacles est un jeu simple dans lequel le joueur doit tenter de frapper le but avec la rondelle.
Pour y jouer, nous devons au moins crer la rondelle du joueur et le but. Pour crer des obstacles, nous utilisons l'instruction obstacle.create().

Instruction puck.create()

L'instruction puck.create() est utilise pour crer la rondelle du joueur aux coordonnes indiques. L'instruction puck.create() a 3 paramtres obligatoires. Les paramtres doivent tre indiqus dans l'ordre suivant: puck.create(x, y, forme).
La coordonne en x doit tre un nombre entre 0 et 30 et est obligatoire
La coordonne en y doit tre un nombre entre 0 et 22 et est obligatoire
La forme doit tre l'une des suivantes: "square", "triangle", "circle", "hexagon", et est obligatoire
Exemples de puck.create()
puck.create(2, 11, "circle"); // cre une rondelle en forme de cercle  (2,11)
puck.create(2, 11); // incorrect: la forme est obligatoire
puck.create(22, 15, triangle); // incorrect: le mot "triangle" doit tre entour de guillemets (" ")
puck.create("hexagon", 10, 11); // incorrect: la forme doit venir aprs les coordonnes

Instruction goal.create()

L'instruction goal.create() est utilise pour crer le but du jeu aux coordonnes indiques. L'instruction goal.create() a 2 paramtres obligatoires. Les paramtres doivent tre indiqus dans l'ordre suivant: goal.create(x, y).
La coordonne en x doit tre un nombre entre 0 et 30 et est obligatoire
La coordonne en y doit tre un nombre entre 0 et 22 et est obligatoire
Exemples de goal.create()
goal.create(20, 11); // cre le but  (20,11)
goal.create(32, 11); // incorrect: la coordonne en x ne doit pas dpasser 30
goal.Create(15, 11); // incorrect: le mot "create" prend un "c" minuscule

units.tips:
Sortie

Une sortie est une information qui nous est retourne par un programme. Les sons mis par un haut-parleur, ou une page sortant d'une imprimante sont des exemples de sorties.
L'instruction console.log() permet de crer des sorties de type texte.

Instruction console.log()

L'instruction console.log() permet de crer une sortie de type texte. L'instruction a un paramtre, qui est habituellement une chane. Le paramtre est crit dans la sortie du programme, c'est--dire dans la console.
Remarquez que la chane donne comme paramtre peut aussi tre la concatnation de plusieurs chanes.
Exemples de console.log()
console.log("Bonjour!"); // affiche: Bonjour!
console.log("Bonjour " + "le monde!"); // affiche la chane concatne: Bonjour le monde!
console.log(Bonjour!); // incorrect: la chane doit tre entoure de guillemets (" ")

console.log(?);
units.solution:

console.log(prenom);
units.tips:
Affectation d'une valeur une variable

Affecter une valeur une variable signifie lui donner une valeur. Nous pouvons donner une valeur une variable en indiquant son nom suivi de l'oprateur d'affectation (=) et d'une valeur.
Si nous souhaitons crer une variable, nous devons utiliser l'instruction var avant le nom de la variable. L'instruction var est requise pour crer une nouvelle variable. Toutefois, elle ne devrait pas tre utilise avec une variable existante.
Exemple d'affectation une nouvelle variable et une variable existante
var nomVariable = 42; // donne la valeur 42  une nouvelle variable
nomVariable = 52; // donne la valeur 52  une variable existante
La valeur que nous donnons une variable peut tre de diffrents types et peut mme tre le rsultat d'un calcul.
Exemples d'affectations
var vies; // cre une nouvelle variable appele vies avec une valeur non dfinie
var pointage = 42; // cre une variable appele pointage et lui donne la valeur 42
vies = 3; // donne une valeur de 3  la variable vies existante
pointage = 2 + 2; // affecte la somme de 2 + 2 (4)  la variable pointage
var nom = "EduCode"; // cre une variable appele nom et lui donne la valeur de "EduCode"

Instruction console.log()

L'instruction console.log() permet de crer une sortie de type texte. L'instruction a un paramtre, qui est habituellement une chane. Le paramtre est crit dans la sortie du programme, c'est--dire dans la console.
Remarquez que la chane donne comme paramtre peut aussi tre la concatnation de plusieurs chanes.
Exemples de console.log()
console.log("Bonjour!"); // affiche: Bonjour!
console.log("Bonjour " + "le monde!"); // affiche la chane concatne: Bonjour le monde!
console.log(Bonjour!); // incorrect: la chane doit tre entoure de guillemets (" ")

Instruction console.log() et variables

Nous pouvons utiliser une variable comme paramtre de l'instruction console.log(). La valeur de la variable est crite dans la sortie du programme, c'est--dire dans la console.
Remarquez que le nom de la variable ne doit pas tre entour de guillemets, sinon il sera trait comme une chane.
Exemples de console.log() avec une variable
var monNom = "EduCode";
console.log(monNom); // affiche le texte: EduCode
var unNombre = 42;
console.log(unNombre); // affiche le nombre: 42
var uneVariable = "Programmer est amusant!";
console.log(uneVariable); // affiche le texte: Programmer est amusant!
console.log("uneVariable"); // affiche le texte: uneVariable

units.tips:
Entre

Une entre est une information que nous donnons un programme. Par exemple, une calculatrice prend deux nombres en entre, effectue un calcul en les additionnant, puis cre une sortie en affichant le rsultat l'cran.
L'instruction prompt() permet de crer une entre de type texte.

Instruction prompt()

L'instruction prompt() cre une entre de type texte. L'instruction a un paramtre. Normalement, le paramtre est une chane. La valeur du paramtre est affiche au-dessus de la bote de saisie, o l'utilisateur peut saisir du texte.
L'instruction retourne une chane, qui est la valeur entre par l'utilisateur dans la bote de saisie. Nous devons habituellement conserver cette valeur dans une variable afin de pouvoir l'utiliser plus tard.
Exemples de prompt()
var monNom = prompt("Quel est votre nom?"); // l'utilisateur entre: EduCode
console.log("Votre nom est " + monNom); // affiche le texte: Votre nom est EduCode
var monAge = prompt("Quel ge avez-vous?"); // l'utilisateur entre: 16

var quotient = 10 / 5; // 10 divis par 5 est gal  2

Les valeurs des variables ont un type. Il est important de considrer le type des donnes que contiennent les variables lorsque nous les utilisons dans des oprations. Parmi les types courants, nous retrouvons les nombres et les chanes.

Chanes

Les chanes sont des valeurs que nous pouvons utiliser pour reprsenter du texte. Une chane doit toujours tre entoure de guillemets. Il est possible de combiner plusieurs chanes en une seule l'aide de l'oprateur de concatnation (+).
Exemples de chanes
var monNom = "EduCode";
var unePhrase = "Programmer est amusant!";
var uneAutrePhrase = Programmer est amusant!; // incorrect: la chane doit tre entoure de guillemets (" ")
Les chanes peuvent aussi tre utilises pour reprsenter des nombres. Cependant, ces nombres ne peuvent pas tre utiliss dans des oprations mathmatiques sans d'abord les convertir en nombres l'aide de l'instruction Number().
Exemples de chanes reprsentant des nombres
var unNombreDansUneChaine = "450"; // reprsentation en texte de 450
var resultat = unNombreDansUneChaine + 10; // resultat est 45010

Nombres

Les nombres sont des valeurs que nous pouvons utiliser dans des oprations mathmatiques. Les nombres doivent tre crits sans espaces entre les chiffres et les dcimales doivent tre spares par un point (.) et non une virgule (,).
Exemples de nombres
var unNombre = 42;
var unTresGrandNombre = 10000000;
var unAutreGrandNombre = 100 000 000; // incorrect: ne doit pas contenir d'espaces
var unNombreDecimal = 1.15;
var unAutreNombreDecimal = 1,15; // incorrect: les dcimales doivent tre spares par un point

Combinaison de chanes avec d'autres valeurs (concatnation)

Le rsultat de l'oprateur + dpend du type des donnes qui sont utilises.
Si les deux valeurs sont des nombres, alors l'oprateur + fonctionne comme l'oprateur d'addition en mathmatiques.
Toutefois, si les valeurs sont des chanes, le signe + est alors l'oprateur de concatnation et combine les valeurs pour former une chane.
Exemples avec signe +
var resultat = 10 + 10; // nombre + nombre, resultat est 20 (nombre)
resultat = "10" + "10"; // chane + chane, resultat est 1010 (chane)
resultat = "10" + 10; // chane + nombre, resultat est 1010 (chane)
resultat = "10" + (10 + 10); // chane + (nombre + nombre), resultat est 1020 (chane)

units.description:
votre tour!
Construisons un programme qui calcule notre salaire brut et net la fin de chaque semaine de travail. Pour ce faire, nous devons multiplier le nombre d'heures travailles par le salaire horaire. Le salaire brut est le salaire avant impt, tandis que le salaire net est le salaire aprs impt. Par exemple, si nous travaillons 40 heures un salaire de 15$ de l'heure et que le taux d'impt est de 15%, alors notre salaire brut est de 600,00$ et notre salaire net est de 510,00$.

  3. Crer une nouvelle variable appele salaireBrut et lui donner le produit de salaireHoraire multipli par heuresSemaine. Indice: le symbole de multiplication est l'astrisque (*).
  4. Crer une nouvelle variable appele deduction et lui donner le produit de salaireBrut multipli par tauxImpot.
  5. Crer une nouvelle variable appele salaireNet et lui donner le rsultat de salaireBrut moins deduction.

Oprateurs relationnels

Les oprateurs relationnels nous permettent de comparer des valeurs. Elles retournent toujours une valeur boolenne.
Les oprateurs relationnels sont: plus grand (>), plus petit (<), plus grand ou gal (>=), plus petit ou gal (<=), galit (==) et ingalit (!=).
Exemples d'oprateurs relationnels
var resultat = 10 > 5; // true (vrai), car 10 est plus grand que 5
resultat = 10 < 5; // false (faux), car 10 n'est pas plus petit que 5
resultat = 10 <= 10; // true (vrai), car 10 est gal  10
resultat = 10 < 10; // false (faux), car 10 n'est pas plus petit que 10
resultat = 15 == 10; // false (faux), car 15 n'est pas gal  10
resultat = 15 == 15; // true (vrai), car 15 est gal  15
resultat = 5 != 7; // true (vrai), car 5 n'est pas gal  7
resultat = 5 != 5; // false (faux), car 5 est gal  5

units.tips:
Comparaison de chanes avec les oprateurs d'galit et d'ingalit

Les oprateurs relationnels d'galit et d'ingalit peuvent tre utiliss pour comparer des chanes.
L'oprateur d'galit (==) retourne true (vrai) si les deux chanes sont identiques, en considrant les majuscules et les minuscules.
L'oprateur d'ingalit (!=) retourne true (vrai) si les deux chanes sont diffrentes (c'est--dire, si au moins une lettre est diffrente), en considrant les majuscules et les minuscules.
Comparaison de chanes
var resultat = "EduCode" == "EduCode"; // true (vrai)
resultat = "Coder" == "Programmer"; // false (faux)
resultat = "EduCode" == "Educode"; // false (faux), car le "C" est en majuscule puis en minuscule
resultat = "EduCode" != "EduCode"; // false (faux), car les deux chanes sont identiques
resultat = "EduCode" != "Educode"; // true (vrai), car le "C" est en majuscule puis en minuscule

Oprateurs relationnels

Les oprateurs relationnels nous permettent de comparer des valeurs. Elles retournent toujours une valeur boolenne.
Les oprateurs relationnels sont: plus grand (>), plus petit (<), plus grand ou gal (>=), plus petit ou gal (<=), galit (==) et ingalit (!=).
Exemples d'oprateurs relationnels
var resultat = 10 > 5; // true (vrai), car 10 est plus grand que 5
resultat = 10 < 5; // false (faux), car 10 n'est pas plus petit que 5
resultat = 10 <= 10; // true (vrai), car 10 est gal  10
resultat = 10 < 10; // false (faux), car 10 n'est pas plus petit que 10
resultat = 15 == 10; // false (faux), car 15 n'est pas gal  10
resultat = 15 == 15; // true (vrai), car 15 est gal  15
resultat = 5 != 7; // true (vrai), car 5 n'est pas gal  7
resultat = 5 != 5; // false (faux), car 5 est gal  5

Une erreur commune qui survient en utilisant l'oprateur d'galit (==) est d'crire un seul signe gal (=). Au lieu de comparer les deux valeurs, le programme fera une opration d'affectation.
Exemple d'affectation au lieu de comparaison
var x = 10;
console.log(x = 15); // plutt que de vrifier si x est gal  15, x prend la valeur 15

units.tips:
Instruction if

L'instruction if est un type d'instruction conditionnelle qui nous permet de contrler si un bloc de code sera excut. Elles comportent deux parties: une condition boolenne et du code qui sera excut si la condition est vraie.
Exemple d'instruction if
var argent = 8;
if(argent > 5) // la condition boolenne, entre parenthses
{
  // les instructions qui se trouvent entre les accolades ({})
  // seront seulement excutes si argent est plus grand que 5
  console.log("Vous pouvez acheter le jeu!");
}
Dans l'exemple ci-dessus, si la valeur de la variable argent est plus grande que 5, alors l'instruction console.log() est excute, sinon aucune instruction n'est excute.

Condition

Les conditions sont comme des questions auxquelles nous ne pouvons rpondre que par vrai ou faux. Nous utilisons des conditions pour contrler diverses parties de notre code, comme les instructions conditionnelles et les boucles. Une condition retourne toujours true (vrai) ou false (faux).
Pour crer une condition, nous pouvons utiliser n'importe quel oprateur relationnel.
Exemple de condition

{
  console.log("maVariable est plus grande que 10");

L'instruction console.log() permet de crer une sortie de type texte. L'instruction a un paramtre, qui est habituellement une chane. Le paramtre est crit dans la sortie du programme, c'est--dire dans la console.

Bloc de code

Un bloc de code est un outil spcial servant grouper une ou plusieurs instructions. Les instructions ainsi groupes seront excutes selon une certaine condition.

{
  // ce bloc de code est excut
  console.log("poids est plus grand que 4!");
}

{
  // ce bloc de code est excut aussi
  console.log("poids est plus grand que 8!");
}
if(poids > 16)
{
  // ce bloc de code est excut aussi
  console.log("poids est plus grand que 16!");
}
Dans l'exemple ci-dessus, nous obtenons trois messages: "poids est plus grand que 4!", "poids est plus grand que 8!" et "poids est plus grand que 16!". Mme si la premire instruction if est vraie, les deuxime et troisime instructions if sont tout de mme excutes.

{

  console.log("poids est plus grand que 4!");

{
  // ce bloc de code n'est PAS excut, car le premier bloc a t excut
  console.log("poids est plus grand que 8!");
}

{
  // ce bloc de code n'est PAS excut, car le premier bloc a t excut
  console.log("poids est plus grand que 16!");
}

votre tour!
Ajoutons une autre destination la machine de tri d'Octo Poste. La nouvelle destination est les tats-Unis. Les paquets destination des tats-Unis pesant moins de 10 kg ont un prix d'expdition rduit de 11$.
units.task:
Pour complter cet exercice avec succs, vous devez :
  1. Remplacer le point d'interrogation par une instruction if. La condition de cette instruction if doit vrifier si la valeur de poids est plus petite que 10. l'intrieur du bloc de code de cette instruction if, donnez prix la valeur 11.
units.tips:
Instructions conditionnelles imbriques

Nous pouvons crer une instruction conditionnelle imbrique en mettant une instruction if l'intrieur du bloc de code d'une autre instruction if.
De cette faon, nous pouvons vrifier la premire condition avant de vrifier la deuxime condition. La premire instruction if s'appelle l'instruction if externe, tandis que la deuxime instruction if s'appelle l'instruction if interne.
Exemple d'instruction conditionnelle imbrique
// instruction if externe
if(vies > 0) // cette condition est vrifie en premier
{
  // instruction if interne
  if(pointage > 100) // cette condition est seulement vrifie si la premire est vraie
  {
    console.log("Vous avez gagn!");
  }
}

La condition de cette instruction if doit vrifier si la valeur de poids est plus petite que 10. l'intrieur du bloc de code de cette instruction if, donnez prix la valeur 20.

  // instruction if interne

  {
    console.log("Vous avez gagn!");
  }
}

Instruction else if

L'instruction else if est une autre instruction conditionnelle que nous pouvons ajouter une instruction if existante pour ajouter un ou plusieurs blocs de code contrls par des conditions.
Remarquez que mme si vous ajoutez plusieurs instructions else if une instruction if, un seul bloc de code sera excut. Les conditions sont vrifies en ordre, de haut en bas, et ds qu'une condition est vraie, le bloc de code correspondant est excut et les autres conditions sont ignores.
Exemple d'instructions else if multiples
var maVariable = 11;

if(maVariable > 15)
{
  // pas excut: la condition est fausse
  console.log("maVariable est plus grande que 15!");
}
else if(maVariable > 10)
{
  // excut: la condition est vraie
  console.log("maVariable est plus grande que 10!");
}
else if(maVariable > 5)
{
  // pas excut: la condition est vraie, mais un autre bloc de code a dj t excut
  console.log("maVariable est plus grande que 5!");
}
Dans l'exemple ci-dessus, puisque la variable maVariable a la valeur 11, le message "maVariable est plus grande que 10!" est affich. Le premier bloc de code est ignor car maVariable n'est pas plus grande que 15 et le dernier bloc de code est aussi ignor car le deuxime bloc de code a dj t excut.

votre tour!
Nous allons ajouter un message pour chacune des destinations, afin d'indiquer l'utilisateur la destination des paquets qui passent dans la machine.
units.task:
Pour complter cet exercice avec succs, vous devez :
  1. Remplacer le premier point d'interrogation par une instruction console.log() qui affiche le message: "Paquet pour le Canada!".
  2. Remplacer le deuxime point d'interrogation par une instruction console.log() qui affiche le message: "Paquet pour les tats-Unis!".
  3. Remplacer le troisime point d'interrogation par une instruction console.log() qui affiche le message: "Paquet pour la France!".
units.tips:
Instruction console.log()

L'instruction console.log() permet de crer une sortie de type texte. L'instruction a un paramtre, qui est habituellement une chane. Le paramtre est crit dans la sortie du programme, c'est--dire dans la console.
Remarquez que la chane donne comme paramtre peut aussi tre la concatnation de plusieurs chanes.
Exemples de console.log()
console.log("Bonjour!"); // affiche: Bonjour!
console.log("Bonjour " + "le monde!"); // affiche la chane concatne: Bonjour le monde!
console.log(Bonjour!); // incorrect: la chane doit tre entoure de guillemets (" ")

  1. Remplacer le premier point d'interrogation par une instruction else. l'intrieur du bloc de code de cette instruction else, donnez prix la valeur 35.
  2. Remplacer le deuxime point d'interrogation par une autre instruction else. l'intrieur du bloc de code de cette instruction else, donnez prix la valeur 55.
units.tips:
Instructions else et else if dans une instruction if imbrique

Les instructions conditionnelles imbriques peuvent avoir des instructions else et des instructions else if.
Il est trs utile d'aligner les blocs de code, afin de pouvoir distinguer les instructions qui font partie de l'instruction externe et celles qui font partie de l'instruction interne.
Exemple d'instruction conditionnelle imbrique complexe
if(vies > 0) // instruction if externe
{
  if(pointage > 100) // instruction if interne
  {
    console.log("Vous avez gagn!");
  }
  else if // cette instruction else if fait partie de l'instruction if interne
  {
    console.log("Vous n'avez pas suffisamment de points!");
  }
}
else // cette instruction else fait partie de l'instruction if externe
{
  console.log("Vous avez perdu!");
}

L'instruction if est un type d'instruction conditionnelle qui nous permet de contrler si un bloc de code sera excut. Elles comportent deux parties: une condition boolenne et du code qui sera excut si la condition est vraie.
Exemple d'instruction if
var argent = 8;
if(argent > 5) // la condition boolenne, entre parenthses
{
  // les instructions qui se trouvent entre les accolades ({})
  // seront seulement excutes si argent est plus grand que 5
  console.log("Vous pouvez acheter le jeu!");
}
Dans l'exemple ci-dessus, si la valeur de la variable argent est plus grande que 5, alors l'instruction console.log() est excute, sinon aucune instruction n'est excute.

  }

Oprateurs relationnels

Les oprateurs relationnels nous permettent de comparer des valeurs. Elles retournent toujours une valeur boolenne.
Les oprateurs relationnels sont: plus grand (>), plus petit (<), plus grand ou gal (>=), plus petit ou gal (<=), galit (==) et ingalit (!=).
Exemples d'oprateurs relationnels
var resultat = 10 > 5; // true (vrai), car 10 est plus grand que 5
resultat = 10 < 5; // false (faux), car 10 n'est pas plus petit que 5
resultat = 10 <= 10; // true (vrai), car 10 est gal  10
resultat = 10 < 10; // false (faux), car 10 n'est pas plus petit que 10
resultat = 15 == 10; // false (faux), car 15 n'est pas gal  10
resultat = 15 == 15; // true (vrai), car 15 est gal  15
resultat = 5 != 7; // true (vrai), car 5 n'est pas gal  7
resultat = 5 != 5; // false (faux), car 5 est gal  5

units.name: Les trois tats
units.description:
votre tour!
La matire qui nous entoure est habituellement dans l'un des trois tats suivants: liquide, gazeux et solide. Par exemple, l'eau peut se trouver sous forme liquide, sous forme gazeuse lorsqu'elle est en vapeur et sous forme solide que nous appelons glace. Lorsque la matire atteint une certaine temprature, elle change d'tat. Ces tempratures ont des noms spciaux:
  • Lorsque la matire passe de l'tat liquide l'tat solide, la temprature est le point de conglation.
  • Lorsque la matire passe de l'tat solide l'tat liquide, la temprature est le point de fusion.
  • Lorsque la matire passe de l'tat liquide l'tat gazeux, la temprature est le point d'bullition.
Construisons un programme qui analyse les points de conglation, de fusion et d'bullition de l'eau et du mercure. L'eau gle si la temprature est plus petite que 0 degrs Celsius, fond entre 0 et 100 degrs et bout si la temprature est plus grande que 100 degrs Celsius. Le mercure gle si la temprature est plus petite que -38,8 degrs Celsius, fond entre -38,8 et 356,73 degrs et bout si la temprature est plus grande que 356,73 degrs Celsius.

questions.question: Vrai ou faux. Une instruction if peut avoir plusieurs instructions if l'intrieur de son bloc de code.

answers.explanation: Les blocs de code sont utiliss pour grouper les instructions et nous pouvons mettre n'importe quelle instruction  l'intrieur.

questions.question: Choisissez tous les noncs qui sont vrais.

answers.answer: Une instruction if l'intrieur du bloc de code d'une autre instruction if est toujours excute, mme si la condition de la premire instruction if est fausse.
Une instruction if l'intrieur du bloc de code d'une autre instruction if est seulement excute si la condition de la premire instruction if est vraie.
answers.explanation: Une instruction if l'intrieur d'un bloc de code est seulement excute si le bloc de code est excut.

answers.answer: Une instruction if l'intrieur du bloc de code d'une autre instruction if ne peut pas avoir une instruction else.
Une instruction if l'intrieur du bloc de code d'une autre instruction if ne peut pas avoir une instruction else if.

questions.question:
Quelle est la sortie du programme suivant?
var temperature = 16;
  
if(temperature > 10)
{
  console.log("temperature est plus grande que 10");

  if(temperature > 15)
  {
    console.log("temperature est plus grande que 15");
  }
}

answers.answer: Deux messages: temperature est plus grande que 10 et temperature est plus grande que 15
answers.explanation: Puisque temperature > 10 est vrai, le premier message est affich. Puisque le bloc de code est excut et que temperature > 15 est aussi vrai, le deuxime message est aussi affich.

questions.question:
Quelle est la sortie du programme suivant?
var temperature = 2;

if(temperature > 10)
{
  console.log("temperature est plus grande que 10");

  if(temperature > 15)
  {
    console.log("temperature est plus grande que 15");
  }
}
else
{
  console.log("temperature est plus petite que 10");
}

answers.answer: Deux messages: temperature est plus grande que 10 et temperature est plus grande que 15

answers.explanation: Puisque temperature > 10 est faux, le bloc de code de l'instruction else est excut.

questions.question:
Quelle est la sortie du programme suivant?
var temperature = 11;

if(temperature > 10)
{
  if(temperature > 15)
  {
    console.log("temperature est plus grande que 15");
  }
  else
  {
    console.log("temperature est entre 10 et 15");
  }
}
else
{
  console.log("temperature est plus petite que 10");
}

answers.explanation: Puisque temperature > 10 est vrai, le bloc de code de la premire instruction if est excut. Puis, puisque temperature > 15 est faux, le bloc de code de la premire instruction else est excut.

answers.answer: Deux messages: temperature est plus petite que 10 et temperature est entre 10 et 15

questions.question:
Quelle est l'erreur dans le programme suivant?
var poids = 3;
  
if(poids > 10)
{
  console.log("poids est plus grand que 10");

  if(poids < 5)
  {
    console.log("poids est plus petit que 5");
  }
}

answers.answer: La deuxime instruction if ne peut jamais tre excute. Un nombre ne peut pas tre la fois plus grand que 10 et plus petit que 5.
answers.explanation: Le code contient une erreur de logique. L'instruction if interne devrait tre l'extrieur du bloc de code de la premire instruction if.

answers.answer: Une instruciton if se trouve l'intrieur du bloc de code d'une autre instruction if.
Les conditions des deux instructions if devraient tre changes.

questions.question:
Quelle est l'erreur dans le programme suivant?
var poids = 7;

if(poids < 15)
{
  console.log("poids est plus petit que 15");

  else
  {
    console.log("poids est plus grand que 15");
  }
}

answers.answer: L'instruction else doit tre remplace par une instruction if qui vrifie si poids est plus grand que 15.
L'instruction else l'intrieur du bloc de code de la premire instruction if doit tre dplace aprs l'instruction if.
answers.explanation: Une instruction else ne peut pas apparatre seule dans une instruction conditionnelle. Pour que le code soit valide, l'instruction else doit tre dplace l'extrieur du bloc de code, tout de suite aprs la dernire accolade fermante (}).

Oprateur ET (&&)

L'oprateur ET est un oprateur logique qui nous permet de vrifier si deux ou plusieurs valeurs boolennes sont vraies.
Une expression qui utilise l'oprateur ET est seulement vraie si toutes les conditions qui forment l'expression sont vraies.

Nous pouvons utiliser plus d'un oprateur ET pour vrifier plusieurs conditions dans une seule expression. Pour que l'expression soit vraie, chaque condition doit aussi tre vraie. Si une seule condition est fausse, l'expression entire est aussi fausse.
Oprateurs ET multiples
if(faim == true && argent > 5 && jour == "mardi")
{
  console.log("Vous pouvez acheter de la pizza!");
}
Si vous avez faim et que vous avez plus de 5$ et que nous sommes mardi, vous pouvez acheter de la pizza.
Si vous n'avez pas faim, mais que vous avez plus de 5$ et que nous sommes mardi, vous ne pouvez pas acheter de pizza.
Si vous avez faim, mais que vous n'avez pas plus de 5$ et que nous sommes mardi, vous ne pouvez pas acheter de pizza.
Si vous avez faim et que vous avez plus de 5$, mais que nous ne sommes pas mardi, vous ne pouvez pas acheter de pizza.
Si vous n'avez pas faim, que vous n'avez pas plus de 5$ et que nous ne sommes pas mardi, vous ne pouvez pas acheter de pizza.

units.tips:
Cration et utilisation d'une variable

Pour crer une variable, nous utilisons l'instruction var suivie d'un nom.
Pour donner une valeur une variable que nous avons cre, nous utilisons son nom, sans l'instruction var.
Par dfaut, la valeur d'une variable est undefined, c'est--dire non dfinie.
Exemple de cration et d'utilisation d'une variable
var pointage; // cre une nouvelle variable appele pointage avec une valeur non dfinie
pointage = 42; // donne la valeur 42  la variable pointage existante
var vies = 3; // cre une nouvelle variable appele vies et lui donne la valeur 3

Instruction if

L'instruction if est un type d'instruction conditionnelle qui nous permet de contrler si un bloc de code sera excut. Elles comportent deux parties: une condition boolenne et du code qui sera excut si la condition est vraie.
Exemple d'instruction if
var argent = 8;
if(argent > 5) // la condition boolenne, entre parenthses
{
  // les instructions qui se trouvent entre les accolades ({})
  // seront seulement excutes si argent est plus grand que 5
  console.log("Vous pouvez acheter le jeu!");
}
Dans l'exemple ci-dessus, si la valeur de la variable argent est plus grande que 5, alors l'instruction console.log() est excute, sinon aucune instruction n'est excute.

Remarquez que mme si vous ajoutez plusieurs instructions else if une instruction if, un seul bloc de code sera excut. Les conditions sont vrifies en ordre, de haut en bas, et ds qu'une condition est vraie, le bloc de code correspondant est excut et les autres conditions sont ignores.
